awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Experimental and Theoretical Investigation of the Electrodynamics and Structuring of the Low-latitude Ionosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award will advance our understanding of the space near Earth (geospace) with focus on the variability of the electric fields over height and over time within the low latitude ionosphere, which is that region of the upper atmosphere located between approximately 50 and 300 miles altitude. It is formed by a mixture of atmospheric neutral species and charged particles (ions and electrons) created, mostly, by the absorption of solar radiation. The dynamical behavior of geospace depends on various physical processes occurring in the Sun, in the Sun-Earth environment, and in the lower (below 50 miles) atmosphere. The research plan of this award will combine existing ground-based radar measurements made in Peru with space-based measurements.  These results together with new measurements would be utilized to assist the development of computer numerical models that would provide better specification of the low-latitude ionosphere and its dependence upon local time, solar flux levels, and geomagnetic activity. The broader impact of the funded work will provide professional training for undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics. The project will also enhance the curriculum of the Physics program at UT Dallas. Finally, the project is expected to also increase public literacy about scientific and technological aspects of the Earth's geospace environment through the medium of public lectures presented at the Space Center at regular intervals.

The research plan to combine measurements and modeling would achieve greatly-improved understanding of fundamental physical processes responsible for the ionospheric dynamical behavior. The outcomes of this study will also help to evaluate, more accurately than currently possible, the impact of the ionosphere in the propagation of radio waves used by various technological systems (GPS, telecommunications, remote sensing, over-the-horizon radars, etc.) providing strong relevance to societal needs in connection with space weather forecasting.

por.por_cntn:
The Earth's ionosphere is a region of the upper atmosphere located between about 35 and 1,000 miles altitude. It is a region characterized by a relatively large density of free ions and electrons created mostly by solar photoionization. This ionospheric gas is important because it allows fundamental studies of plasmas without concerns related to plasma creation and containment. The ionospheric plasma is also important because it affects the propagation of radio waves used for communication, remote sensing and navigation (e.g., GPS).

Equatorial spread F or simply ESF is the general name given to a wide range, in scale sizes, of irregularities that are commonly observed in the low latitude ionospheric plasma density. We currently seek a better understanding of processes favoring the development of ESF irregularities and causing its short-term (day-to-day) variability. We also seek a better understanding of the impact of these irregularities in different types of radio systems.

In this project we dedicated efforts to modeling the motion of the ionospheric plasma at low latitudes and to studies relating this motion to the development of ionospheric plasma structuring including ESF. The research efforts were carried out in parallel with educational and professional training activities.

Accomplishments related to research include: (a) The development of numerical models that describe the motion of the ionospheric plasma at low and mid latitudes. We highlight, in particular, the development of open-source models of the vertical and zonal plasma motion that are now available to the public, and that can be used in different types of studies. (b) A better understanding of the effect of low and mid latitude ionospheric irregularities in L-Band signals used by global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) such as GPS. (c) a better understanding of atypical ESF structures, that is, ESF structures that occur during times (e.g., post-midnight) and or seasons (e.g., June solstice) when ESF is not expected to occur. (d) Establishment of a new research lab within the UTD's Center for Space Sciences. 

Accomplishments related to education and professional training include: (a) The support of five different graduate (PhD) students in physics and electrical engineering. Three students already graduated. (b) Creation of research and professional training opportunities related to atmospheric and space sciences for undergraduate students in physics, electrical engineering, and computer science. (c) Improvement of teaching practices in courses related to electromagnetism and computational methods.
